definition:
Let $f \colon G \subset {\mathbb{C}}^n \to {\mathbb{C}}$ be a $C^2$
(twice continuously differentiable) function. $f$ is called
[*pluriharmonic*]{} if for every complex line
$\{ a + b z \mid z \in {\mathbb{C}} \}$ the function
$z \mapsto f(a + bz)$ is harmonic on the set
$\{ z \in {\mathbb{C}} \mid a + b z \in G \}$.

Note that every pluriharmonic function is a harmonic function, but not
the other way around. Further it can be shown that for holomorphic
functions of several complex variables the real (and the imaginary)
parts are locally pluriharmonic functions. Do note however that just
because a function is harmonic in each variable separately does not
imply that it is pluriharmonic.
